div.head: 5 / 16 September 1708. – Translation of [the head of the Ambassadorial Chancery,] Count [Gavrila Ivanovich] Golloffkin's letter to [the Envoy Extraordinary of Great Britain to Russia,] Mr. [Charles] Whitworth, about the affront offerd [to] the Russian Ambassador in London [Andrei Artamonovich Matveev], dated from the camp at Grigorkow 16. Sept[ember] 1708 TNA Kew, Russia, no. SP 91-5, f. 69-71v. English translation.
div.p: Translation of Count Golloffkin's Letter to Mr. Whitworth, about the affront offerd [to] the Russian Ambassador in London, dated from the camp at Grigorkow 16. Sept[ember] 1708

I have received your letter of the 3./14. Inst[ant] some days ago, by which I first was surprised, but when the particular Relation of our Ambassador Mr. Matveoff afterwards came on, was quite astonish’d, to learn the unheard off inhuman Proceedings and affront offer’d His Czarish Majesty himself in the person of His Ambassador at London, to the greatest violation of the Law of Nations. The Circumstances of this injury as the Ambassador has given an account to His Czarish Majesty, are so very Extraordinary, that it must be said to be an Instance without Example; namely that an Ambassador of so great a Prince, under the pretence of orders from a justice of peace, was permitted to be violently attack’d, in the open street, at night, by a parcel of Bailiffs or to call them more properly Highwaymen, his footmen beat off, his coach forceably broke open, these fellows placed by him, his person inhumanely treated with cudgelling, taking away his Sword, cane, and Hat, and tearing his apparel; and when by repeated outerys he had induced several persons to come to his assistance, who rescued him out of the hands of these Highwaymen and brought him into a neighbouring Tavern, to inform themselves of the busines ; the said fellows produced their orders, on which the Ambassador found himself again abandon’d by every one, turn’d over to the

Discretion of these thieves, further abused by them, forceably slung into a Harkney coach, hurried away to a scandalous prison, and there set fast; and notwithstanding He the Ambassador sent some foreign Ministers and English Lords, who were his personal friends and took his part, to acquaint the Secretary of State with these unheard off proceedings, yet he would not be found, but his secretary Walpole came thither, as he gave out of his own accord, and not as you report, dispatch’d by the Secretary of State, much less to the Ambassadors assistance, but perhaps to divert himself with the spectacle ; since he did not make the least offer for his release, nor once examin any person, how they durst thus misuse an Ambassador against the Law of Nations, but went away without doing any thing; so that the Ambassador finding himself exposed without any Protection from the Government, was obliged to buy himself out of this jayl and barbarous hands, would He recover his Liberty, thou no other reason could be given him for this inhumane treatment, than that it was done at the suit of two Tradesmen for fifty pound Sterling, which the Ambass[ador] owd them, notwithstanding he had some time before appointed the next day for the payment of all debts, recredentials, his passport, nor procured a Jacht, so that he could not have gone away from them. His Czarish Majesty cannot do otherwise, than look on this unexpected affront with the greatest resentment, and therefore has graciously order’d me to write to you that you may acquaint Her Majesty of Great Britain, how

sensible His Czarish Majesty is at this proceeding, and that he demands from Her Majesty a great satisfaction proportionable to the affront; to wit, that the Criminals and first the Sheriff, the occasion of all this Mischief may ay least be condemned to death, afterwards diverted of all his Employments and declared infamous that his servants who attack’d the Ambassador as Highwaymen in the open street, and treated him so barbarously, may be actually put to death as the most notorious Robbers and violators of the Law of Nations; and that the Tradesmen (: who probably made this attempt on the Ambassador at the Instigation of some evil persons who were disposed to create a breach between the two crowns :) as well as all others any ways concern’d in this matter, should be also punished according to the severity of the Laws, that Her Majesty may hereby convince the world of Her love to justice, and Her sincere friendship for His Czarish Majesty, as well as wash off the scandal of violating the Law of Nations from Her people, since such an exemple was never known in any Country and much less amongst the Politer sort. For this affair cannot be repaired or made good in any other manner, and in default of such a suitable satisfaction, His Czarish Majesty shall be oblig’d to do himself full justice, thou he would not willingly go so far, because of the Esteem and friendship he has for Her Majesty; to prevent which ill Consequences, you as an experienc’d Minister and true servant of the Queen, will use your best endeavours by your representations, both to Her Majesty and Her Ministers, that the old friendship

and good correspondence, which has all along subsisted between the two Monarchs, and Empires of Great Russia and Great Britain, may suffer no diminution ; and wee on our sides shall likewise employ our best offices not to let it come to such ill effect.

As to the disagreable accident which you mention, happen’d to you in our Country, from some ignorant people, you will easily judge they cannot be brought into comparison with the unheard off affront offer’d to our Ambassador, nevertheless we by His Czarish Majesty orders have not suffer’d them to pass without giving you satisfaction; for the first, when certain people who did not know your servants, had the boldness to fling stones at them; thou they did not touch your person in the least, yet the underwent hard bodily punishment in the presence of one you deputed for that purpose, till he said it was sufficient. As to the sealing up of your furniture in the Consuls warehouse, in the market place, it cannot be construed as any affront to you, since before your journey you did not inform the Posolsky Precasse that your goods would be deposed there as is usuall in like cases, and while the Town Councill had some pretensions on the Consul and other accounts to settle with him about the toll etc. They sealed up the said warehouse not knowing your goods were there; nevertheless His Czarish Majesty so soon as you complained thereof, reprimended the said Town Councill in very severe Terms, and with Indignation let them understand that they should immediately take off the seal from that warehouse where your things were : but for what relates to the Consul

his person cannot be brought into competition with an Envoy and much less an Ambassador, and since he moreover drives a great Trade, he has sometimes disputes with several persons and offices, nevertheless if any thing were put upon him indecently, and complained off by him either to the Czar or the Posolsky Precasse, His Czarish Majesty would not have fail’d to order him sufficient reparation in consideration of the Queen.

Lastly for what relates to the Queens recognition of Lezinsky, which you have communicated to us, by the Queens orders ; but that it was done on repeated solicitations, after a long delay and the example of other Princes, and that Her Majesty had not the last intention to prejudice the Czars interest thereby, but rather assured him of Her unalterable friendship: His Czarish Majesty receives this Declaration with thanks but at the same time refers it to Her Majestys own mature reflection, whether it must not be very sensible to him, that Her Majesty would make this step without any weighty reason, and without giving him any previous notice, in the very instant that His Ministers in London and the Hague were treating of a nearer allyance and conjunction between the two Crowns, and notwithstanding the Republick of Poland had desir’d Her Majesty to deferr it for some little time. It is very true that His Recognition cannot in the least prejudice the Interest of His Czarish Majesty or the common wealth, only that it may awaken some small discontent in his friends, and some pleasure in His Ennemys; but being now pass’d it must be left

as it is, and the Decision thereof referr’d to the Will of God and chance of arms, which alone can decide, who is to keep possession of the Polish throne, and have of late been very favourable to His Majesty ; the Most High God give his further blessin and happy conclusion hereof, to whose allmighty protection & recommend you and remain.
